review_title: rewarding experience but demanding workload, and potential bureaucratic hurdles.
pros: Intellectual Stimulation and Collaboration: The academic environment at UCL is vibrant and intellectually stimulating. Colleagues from various disciplines frequently collaborate on research projects, fostering an inclusive community of knowledge-sharing. This interdisciplinary approach enriches the learning and teaching experience. Diverse and Inquisitive Student Body: UCL's student population is internationally diverse, bringing a wide array of perspectives to the classroom. This diversity often results in rich and engaging discussions, enhancing the teaching experience. Support for Research: UCL provides strong support for its faculty's research, with ample funding opportunities and a commitment to academic freedom. The availability of cutting-edge resources and labs further assists in research pursuits. Location: The central London location offers both cultural richness and easy access to other academic and research institutions. The opportunity to live and work in one of the world's most vibrant cities is a clear advantage.
cons: Intense Workload: The workload can be demanding, especially with high teaching loads, administrative duties, and the expectation of producing high-quality research. Work-life balance can be challenging to maintain. Large Classes: Some classes at UCL can be quite large, limiting the opportunity for close student-faculty interaction. This may affect the quality of teaching and the personal relationship with students. Bureaucracy: As is often the case in large institutions, there can be a level of bureaucracy that may slow down processes and decision-making.

pros: An an academic there is enough freedom to pursue research.
cons: We used to have a substantial budget for conferences and research allowance, now we don't. This additional funding would count as a year "bonus". Every year there is a new baseline regarding student contact, that keeps increasing The University is focusing too much on expansion, increasing student numbers, but quality of teaching and staff compensation does not follow the same trend.

review_title: Many good people, but a rather poor top heavy management
pros: Decent pay. Supportive colleagues. Flexibility with hours / location of work. Decent expenses when travelling. Generous support for conferences especially when presenting. Lots of opportunity for training & professional development.
cons: Admin & management heavy - i.e. top many administrators and managers per academic. Also, the administrators are largely separate from the departments / research groups which creates an unhelpful duel structure. Too many people in highly paid management positions. Workloads can be intense at times. As is common with much of UK academia, a lot of emphasis on bringing in funding - this ranks above and beyond intellectual work. Quantity over quality in many places - but again this is systemic and not just UCL. Far too much temporary / casual work. Additional work was normally unpaid 'Good for your CV' is no excuse for not paying people for taking on many days of additional work, on .top of what you are paid for.

pros: Salary is acceptable. Most students work a lot.
cons: Absolutely no respect for employees. Constant problems with HR and payroll. No communication between departments and HR. I was harrassed during months because they overpaid me but they couldn't calculate. Just run away, you'll save yourself from a great deal of stress and anxiety. Not worth losing your time.

Some managers are not doing research anymore or lack the relevant technical expertise to lead their research group.

Post-doc positions are quite unfair from a research perspective. You do most of the research and cannnot apply for funding alone. Your managers get credit for your research while sometimes contributing very little.

Work-life balance can be low. Working on weekends is very common, 80 h/week are common when rushing for a deadline.

review_title: Great benefits but sometimes a clash between academic and professional services
pros: It’s a really supportive environment with good benefits and a lot of training available. You will work with educated people from across the world and be surrounded by excellent research. There are lots of jobs at UCL so if you have the right experience you can apply for internal vacancies and secondments and progress accordingly
cons:
Often you will have academics in management roles and while many are lovely, some aren’t interested or efficient with the more administrative and logistical elements of their work so it can be difficult to work with them. They don’t always recognise that they need to keep the role interesting and smooth for their team in order to retain professional service staff as they are more focused on the academic side to their work and work as individuals rather than team members or leaders.

 You get the typical university “siloing” meaning various offices and departments aren’t always in tune with one another which can slow logistical work down. The pay hasn’t gone up enough in relation with inflation, either, and if your office is subject to specific funding then sometimes it will become understaffed over time (a couple years, normally) as the scope of your work increases but the manpower doesn’t. Finally, there are no bonuses and sometimes no opportunities for progression within specific offices, so little incentive to continue to perform highly other than your own good will.


Overall it’s still a good place to work but these things do lead to unpleasant moments and hard days

review_title: Lovely people, but serious flaws with the institution
pros:
- Lovely colleagues - science researchers are all there with the best intentions (to make a difference in the medical world), so the type of people you get to work with is great. Lots of people of all different cultures and backgrounds.
- Relaxed working atmosphere and flexible hours.
- Great city center location with plenty of places to eat and explore around.
- Lots of UCL-wide events/societies for students to join.
cons:
- Little to no extra financial support for PhD students (especially those not on a set PhD programme). Funding for conferences, work equipment etc. is left completely at the discretion of the supervisor. Unfortunately I had a very stingy supervisor, meaning I had to either find my own funding, or not attend conferences at all.
- Badly organised and inefficient HR and admin for the department. Every time my salary needed to be adjusted (typically every 6-12 months), something would go wrong on the admin side, and I would either end up underpaid or not paid at all. As a student on a 17k annual salary living in London, not being paid for a month means that rent and bills can't get paid. This normally takes several weeks of chasing up and sorting before the payment arrives. This happened 5 or 6 times throughout my 4-year PhD.
- Inefficient system to claim back expenses, from conferences or work-related costs. Several times I ended up just paying out of pocket for conferences, because the rules for claiming back expenses kept changing, and I was treated very harshly for 'doing it wrong' (despite not knowing the rule changes at the time). Seems like a UCL way of trying to retain as much money as possible. 
- Lack of departmental funding for events. There is a HUGE discrepancy between the amount of funding each department has. When I was on the PhD committee, we had a budget of £20 PER EVENT (which happened every fortnight). This was for a huge department consisting of 10s of PhD students. This makes it really hard to make friends and socialise with people outside of your own lab.

pros: I guess that the PhD experience depends on many factors, i.e. in which department you are working, who is your supervisor and what is your project. However, being at a top university as UCL helps you especially on a non-research point of view. First I found extremely useful all the university services such as the Career and Doctoral training services, with plenty of non-academic courses and events being organised during the term. Second, being in London is a fantastic opportunity to network. If you are interested in staying in academia you can visit people at nearby universities to discuss your results or to solve possible obstacles in your research. Its incredible how many conferences and science divulgation events are organised in London, you just have to keep your eyes open. If on the other side you are not interested in academia, but after a PhD you want to move into a industry...well, in London you can find Industries in all the possible fields, so even in that case it is easy to find good opportunities.
cons: What I mostly disliked is that UCL is so central in London that all the facilities are badly distributed and of very low quality. Recently there has been a continuous refurbishment of obsolete areas around the Uni, so I guess that UCL is trying to invest strongly on new buildings and new areas. At the moment it is often very complicated to find good office space. In the last three years I have been working in a office with more than 10 people and with no windows.

review_title: One of the best Universities to work with
pros: UCL was funded about 150 years ago, and it is now a world-class university. It's well-recognized in academia, which attracts many super smart people. The facilities of UCL is worth mentioning as well: the historical building for traditional department and the very well equipped new buildings are all very pleasant places to work in. Also its very fast and well rescourseful internet connections, its well-established libroray, and its very centred location, all make UCL a very convinience and pleasant place to work for. Last but not least, it's gym and other facilties all provide cheap membership to UCL staff and students.
cons:
1, Because it is famous, working at UCL can be really competitive. Trying to get a lectureship position in certain areas can be really tough, especially now many American researchers are seeking jobs in top UK univeristies.
2, Some support team are not compitant - I guess because the Universtiy cannot really afford much money for very good people.
3, With its very centred location there are pros and cons. You can go to anywhere easily from UCL, and there are loads of resaurant etc., but affording a flat near work is almost impossilbe if you are just junior staff.

review_title: Beware if applying for research assistant...
pros: The only good reason to work here is that you get a good vacation time, and the job is very flexible. you can come in at 10am as long as you finish your job.
cons: I worked in one of their departments so i can only speak about the dept. Coming in as a research assistant, I had to work with a lot of associated which were all PhD holders. Due to that i was always let out in making decisions or even having an opinion. Most of them assumed i didn't know much because i just have a BS degree. I just performed studies blindly without anyone telling me what the study was really about. most of them just concluded I couldn't even do more instead trying me out first. The worst was when i had to take out trash and was all the items everyone had used. I would have just kept my AA degree if i wanted to do that.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in London, England
pros: smart people but not willing to collaborate
cons: no support, poor salary, poor management

review_title: It's okay as a student job
pros:
I worked for once in the Volunteer Services Unit; yes for once after submitting my application describing my former experience and why I wanted to be a leafleter
- good money (got paid about 30 pounds after working for 3 hours)
- quite relaxing
- can fit around your schedule (but not so true, see below)
cons:
- I found this particular department or just the manager to be poorly organized
- basically he sent the students on the list the emails the same day he wanted you to go flyer, but in reality this was impossible since you must allow enough time for people to rearrange their other stuff as well
- I only got called in twice. The first time I couldn't make it because of my super tight schedule and the reason above.
- basically i also found that they spent a lot of money just to print out those flyers but at the end didn't have enough students to go work for them

review_title: Fantastic place for growth in central London
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: I've been working as a research associate for just over a year and have loved my time at UCL. The access I have has a biomedical researcher to the many world class hospitals as well as research facilities is remarkable. I get to work with people from all around the world and is an incredibly intellectually stimulating environment. My colleagues are hardworking professionals and the bosses are very approachable and supportive. I also get the perks of being in central London.
cons: The UCL admin can be quite slow at times so you may need to consistently nag them to push things to go through. As the university is scattered a bit throughout a major city, your division/department may feel like a small part of a big machine - though to be fair, the different UCL campuses are well situated and possibly more united geographically than other big city universities.

review_title: UCL postgrad experience Human rights MA
pros: Staff are fantastic, helpful and run an incredibly diverse and interesting course. There’s law, philosophy, methodology, politics modules and more (optional modules from any number of departments ranging from history, law, public policy and more) and of the 7 modules you have to do, you can mould 3. The compulsory 4/7 are diverse and captivating in their own respects. Essential weekly reading lists are concise and interesting. Course leader (Saladin Garcia) is a leading academic in the field. He’s interesting and a great public speaker which makes the lectures go by quickly but he balances his confident teaching style with an approachable demeanour, making his seminars an inclusive experience. As someone who was borderline sceptical about how truly academic a masters in human rights would be, I’ve been proven completely wrong by this course.
cons: Seminars can feel too short and always end with a lot more to be said. A 90minute seminar would feel more appropriate given the content we have to get through each week.

pros:
World-renowned institution, agglomeration of world class researchers, highly diversified and exciting research activities and opportunities.

Name of the institution helps to get work accepted at conferences etc.
cons:
Institution is too big and unorganised, i.e. organisational structures and inter-dependencies are not clear. There is a lack of "communal spirit" of being part of one institution. This is mainly due to a huge gap between administration i.e. staff on fixed contracts and researchers on grant-dependent contracts. Communication is difficult. Even when funds are available, things move forward very slowly and sometimes not at all due to internal issues.

In terms of infrastructure, there is no space at all (!), proper offices are basically non-existent, even for senior research staff. IT infrastructure is a mess compared to other universities.

review_title: May as well call us a dogs body/cleaner/personal assistant
job_title: Programmer Administrator UCL Institute of Education in London, England
pros:
Good amount  annual leave 
Some good lower level managers that care about their staff progressing and developing.
cons:
-Most of the ‘old school’ Academics seem to think it’s OK to bully their Programme Administrators and lie to get what they want.  Senior management would rather move the several Administrators on elsewhere, rather than correct the clear behavioural problems of academics. 
-Academics  have often asked me to throw their rubbish out, assuming I’m also a cleaner. 
-Academics are against change, most will be there until death and don’t wish to learn anymore. 
-Clear favouritism shown by senior management 
-No time for staff development or training
-Don’t bother raising concerns with HR as they are too busy dealing with the various cases of sexual harassment in the workplace (or they’re on stress leave or holidays).

pros: Central London location on Bloomsbury surrounded by great food!  A relaxed attitude of excellence which is unique to this place.
cons: Its very much up to you what you get out of the doctorate programme.  No one will push you or stop you - so work hard and pace yourself its a marathon.

pros:
- Decent, although not generous wages for the sector
- Large, and therefore it has a lot of facilities and resources
- Working environments are maintained to a good standard
- The atmosphere for support staff is not combative or competitive
- Support staff do not seem to be intimidated if they do not work overtime, and can request flexible work patterns
- Based in central London, with all of the shops and entertainment that it offers
cons:
- Can be slow-moving and institutionally sluggish
- Large and established enough to sometimes run on rules, rather than results
- Surrounded by building work for the foreseeable future
- Based in central London, with all of the costs and crowds that it implies

job_title: Project Manager/Project Coordinator in London, England
pros: UCL is classifies as being one of the top 10 universities in the World.  Diverse working environment.  As a result it is possible to work on a range of different IT and related projects and initiatives.  Additionally it is possible to work in different departments across the UCL campus.
cons: Teams, particularly working on IT can be very silo'ed.  As a result there is a lot of work that is unnecessarily repeated and very big gaps between projects exist.  For example very little technical material has been recorded to date so operations are dependent on specific individuals memories.

review_title: Fun and interesting place, but occasionally bureaucratic.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Its reputation means they push you hard and expect a lot. To help with this is a lot of support from colleagues and admin. Professional and personal facilities are great and there are a lot of opportunities to meet potential collaborators and contacts. Near the centre of London, good transport links, and great food and entertainment.
cons: Bureaucracy, specially health and safety, and the time required to get projects done by estates. London is expensive.

review_title: Really dynamic and exciting research environment
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: I worked as a postdoctoral research associate in the biochemistry dept.  I found UCL to be a great place to engage in some of the best and most exciting research of my career.  You're surrounded by some of the best scientists in the world, many of whom are also friendly and collaborative.  Many of the courses available to postdocs were of the highest quality, e.g. scientific writing, career development, entrepreneurship.
cons: As with any large institution, there are bureaucratic issues and inevitably not _everyone_ is wonderfully friendly and helpful!  Bear in mind that my experiences may be very 'localised' as UCL is a huge organisation and there will be big variability even from lab to lab.

review_title: Salaries not kept up with the market
pros:
Flexible working
Working from home
Freedom to choose your own projects
cons:
-If you are are in a STEM/business discipline the salary is too low compared to likeminded universities (Imperial october 2018 is boosting all academic salaries up to keep up with the competition). Likewise our grads salaries are likely to be at least 30% more than the salary of a lecturer.
-Proffessional services staff are incompetent. Three weeks to get a a 1 manned costing model is a joke. There is no control over their workload so do as they please.
-In general academia suffers from good resource management thus academics struggle with their time management.

pros: Some really good perks - annual leave, pension, pay and wellbeing policies are all great. There was a good focus on training and professional development for administrative staff and the location itself is wonderful!
cons: Some of the office buildings aren't great to work in - dated and not fit for purpose. Politics around teaching and research are fairly obvious, and it means many of the academic staff are quite stressed and in turn put pressure on administrative staff. Not much communication between departments - probably due to the physical distance between departments that should be working quite closely together.

pros: One of the leading research institutes in the world. It is motivating to know you are studying amongst the best students / researchers in the world. There is plenty of opportunities to take courses which hone your skills outside of your chosen field (entrepreneurship, etc). They also have programs to link researchers to industry.
cons: The administration methods at times were found lacking. The policy to pay PhD stipends every 3 months is something that was a bit of a pain. Also, some students were payed late which is difficult with the day to day expenses of living in London.

review_title: High in rankings yet limited opportunities for Research Staff
pros:
High ranking university with good inflow of funding
Interesting work
Great location with easy transport and range of shops nearby
Generous holiday allowance
cons:
Surprisingly negative culture that fails to identify and act upon opportunities
Minimal communication & collaboration between groups & departments
PI's too busy pulling in large grants and fail to mentor staff
Few opportunities for career development
Low pay and long hours
London living allowance is usually counted as part of your salary even though it is meant to be an additional allowance, though this is not made clear when you are starting.
Very little control over your own career - Completely dependent on your PI
USS Pension continually getting worse

pros: Full of smart, intelligent and down-to-earth people who are devoted to science.   If you want to have a career in science, this is the place to be.  However, if you want a career in administration, there is a lack of progression in UCL, but this may be the same across all universities.
cons: Administrative support is often poor and slow.  The office environment depends on which building you are based in - some offices are small and overcrowded but others are modern and air-conditioned.

pros: Excellent international faculty with eagerness to collaborate. World leading research in most fields. Successful in attracting plenty of research money. Strong ethos of openness and inclusivity. Students are better than average. Great location in central London.
cons: The teaching and administrative load is high and ever increasing. Support staff is of variable quality, and the best ones are invariably overworked. Being in central London, room is at a premium, many Post-Docs and lecturers share offices. Recently a lot of resources have been distracted from research to fund very expensive building projects.

review_title: A great place to work if you want to work for a large employer
pros: Great benefits aligned with other London universities. A large staff means a chance to network with others in the same role.
cons:
Being so large means that an individual can feel 'lost' and feel their voice isn't necessarily heard. Not all staff groups are currently set up with a network, although this seems to be developing slowly.
A long probationary period for roles Grade 7 and above (9 months) means that you may not get a rise in increment points for 18+ months, but depends on joining date.

review_title: Division of medicine (3 campuses) post-grad administrator
pros: Vibrant academic community, interesting campus, good libraries, museums and book store
cons: programme administrators overburdened with work and under-paid compared with other universities, unrealistic targets, too few admin to cope with heavy workloads, several admin colleagues on sick leave due to stress, poor supervision, Portico not user friendly, extremely poor staff training facilities (web design training held in room with poor lighting and many non-working dusty computers) & don't get me started on timetabling! Working in admin in higher education is dire

pros:
+ Good name to have on your CV
+ Many opportunities to growth and develop skills beside your daily work
+ Very big institute so it can be different depending on where you work, but generally you'll been working with very nice and smart people
cons:
- As all junior roles in academia, salary is not great, even though better than other institution around the world
- Sometimes can be difficult to find the right support or help because its a huge university

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Flexible hours, not micromanaged, access to great equipment and usually good funding so can go on nice conferences or training. Some PI’s are amazing and very knowledgable/helpful when assisting research
cons:
Non-collaborative atmosphere and people. The people that get promoted don’t do any actual research but they do brown-nose management which gets them a promotion. All the best people were let to leave.
As PDRAs are employed on 3 year contracts they are not regarded as or treated as staff.
I can only speak of my department others may be different as UCL is a big place.

review_title: Don't come here for a Post-doc
pros:
Central London location
Good access to modern facilities
cons:
Permanent staff treat contract staff as disposable
Jobs advertised at post-doctoral level are in fact technician posts
UCL requires employees to file false VAT declarations to avoid tax on purchases

pros: Relatively good salary, some offices are nice and new, you will likely never work overtime.
cons: Your experience at UCL largely depends on the team you are working with and your supervisor's personality. A lot of big egos, red tape and delays in dealing with queries such as IT issues because of the size of organisation. The environment is very formal and there is lack of motivation throughout; lots of clock-punchers. Very little interaction with colleagues outside of work hours and no feeling of a team. I prefer working for a commercial organisation now.

review_title: Ok for a short time, but don't stay for too long.
pros:
- Lots of freedom and independency, but this may depend on your line manager.
- Potentially interesting work, depending on the project you are working on. 
- UCL is well recognised, so potentially a good stepping stone on the career ladder if willing to move on.
cons:
- Salaries in academia are low and living costs in London are high. 
- The university is quite bureaucratic and run by admin types. 
- Some of the management (professors) are out of touch with reality.
- Career advancement within the university is bad, but this is a reality of academia in general.

pros: UCL is one of the most famous university and you can be fully involved by a marvellous and dynamic multi-ethnic environment. In terms of research, UCL provides complete and innovative facilities to support the researchers. Furthermore, you are surrounded by several stimulating activities and events.
cons: Most of the buildings are quite old and this results in an old environment missing of modernity. HR and administrative support and services are pretty good, but sometime the communication with them is highly challenging and misleading.

pros: SO many. I have the most supportive supervisor, everyone in the lab is super friendly and likes socialising, and most importantly, this job is an amazing platform to go on and do further research because of the quality of the research and the reputation that UCL has. The campus is beautiful and has everything you need around it. I feel fully supported in my role, and my supervisor is very proactive in helping find further funding for whoever needs it.
cons: Some of the labs and equipment are quite dated - I know finding funding is hard but would be nice to have a bit of a revamp!

review_title: Good Benefits but Old Fashioned and Unfriendly
pros: Good benefits, holiday, pension, university facilities, flexible working, a few nice buildings, reasonable salary.  Looks good on your CV.
cons: Old fashioned, takes a long time to change anything, unfriendly staff (in the IT department at least), only people to have permanent jobs are senior people who have been there a while, some staff who have been there a long time are stuck in their ways and not necessarily up to their job in the modern world.

pros: Great presence worldwide in many industries which provides students with excellent employability prospects.  Also provides a world class level of education which leaves all its students knowledgable in their subject area.
cons: If someone does not like the style of a city university,  then the university's lay out is not ideal. The majority of the lectures for everyone are within 5 minutes from the "Main Quad", however, some are up to 15 minutes away.

pros: I was an administrative assistant at UCL while a student there - the hourly pay was pretty good for part-time work, it was relatively undemanding, the people I was working with were nice.
cons: You're not going to learn very much there while working as an administrative assistant - the tasks were mundane, unchallenging, they didn't require very much of you. But I suppose that's to be expected.

pros: You get to work with likeminded people on cutting-edge scientific problems in a truly international environment (in my lab, no nationality is represented more than once). Working hours are flexible (this might depend on your PI and your field of research) and annual leave is generous. There is also a wide range of courses available for career development.
cons: The usual disadvantages of academia: job insecurity (unless you get a senior position, positions are tied to external funding), low salaries compared to the industry. The state of some of the infrastructure shows that funding is notoriously limited.

review_title: Fun part-time role for a student
pros: Very flexible work arrangements around my studies. I didn't need any extra-curricular in that year because I was doing really fun, interesting and intellectual things at work which really stood out from other part-time student jobs.
cons: I felt that sometimes they were wasting money and then were faced with budgetary constraints. The boss wasn't very supportive of development opportunities such as training courses and he often changed his mind as to what was the right way to go forward.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in London, England
pros:
> Centrally located. 
> Excellent facilities, training, and access to the most brilliant mind in the world.  
> Excellent library access.
cons:
> Not much teaching opportunity for PhD student, if they exist, it is a relatively low-paid job. 
> Overstressed and overworked supervisors, always being pressured to bring in more funding to the department. 
> No opportunity to voice our concern about supervisors.

pros: A global university that provides various opportunities for its students and faculty alike. The strength of the university ensures students are provided with adequate material and skills needed to succeed in life, whether that be in a career or just on a day to day basis.
cons: The professors are often occupied with research projects, meaning it is difficult to find one-on-one time. This is further hindered by the large student to teacher ratio currently present.

pros: The part-time pay scale is not a low as in the private sector re administrative or clerical or support jobs if you need a part-time post, there was also some flexibility in some of the jobs if you have child care or studies to complete. Some of the senior staff are very interesting, appreciative and helpful people, but it is very hit and miss as to what the senior staff are going to be like.
cons:
Long hours, never enough staff to ensure things are done properly, and the pay scale is not that great if you are in full time employment as a PA or administrator and working in the centre of london in a stressful pressured environment. Do not be fooled into thinking that working for a university department is a 'soft job'.  Academics can unfortunately live in strange 'bubbles' with a quirky view of life that can be fun at best and toxic at worst. I was lucky that two out of the three bosses I had over a number of years where down to earth and great to work for, but I witnessed dreadful treatment of staff in other departments.  The senior staff (Academic or middle management in support areas) often have expectations can be unrealistic and many have little real appreciation of how support structures best work.  When there are problems with bulling from middle managers, they are moved to different posts and the difficulties continue.  Staff moral therefore becomes low and the 'good staff' don't hang about and simply leave once given the chance to do so.   Often people would rather earn twice the wage for equal levels of stress, which is not hard to do in normal economic times, in a full time post, somewhere in London for one of the bigger firms.
I witnessed senior academic staff treating junior academic and research staff quite badly, but due to the competitive nature of research, junior staff often simply relieved to  employed in their chosen career areas and therefore put up with a great deal more stress, rudeness and difficulties than most would otherwise cope with.

pros: GOod training courses provided for free by many schools of UCL. Qualities are good in general, and they provide you with cerfiticate at the end. many courses are ran few times a year. Good opportunity to learn areas which you are not familiar with
cons: The employment process is long, too much bureaucracy. If you are in a rush to start you work, you might get dissapointed

review_title: Amazing passionate people despite an organisation that is trying but doesn’t quite know how to support them
job_title: Public Engagement Manager in London, England
pros: Extremely passionate people doing amazing work; great work life balance and flexibility; if you are dynamic and driven there is opportunity to carve out new roles and direction under the right managers; if you just want to do your job and go home each day that is supported to;
cons: Everything is geared to supporting research, you are a second class citizen if you are not an academic; there are limited opportunities for advancement or pay rises; professional service roles outside of centralised teams are forgotten about often being managed by academics who have never had proper management training and have no idea of your needs or what you do; annual appraisals are worthless, there are no consequences good or bad (on a personal level) to completing them; lack of clarity on where the organisation stands/draws a line on issues like bullying and harassment so people aren’t empowered to step up and change culture; a commitment to positive change exists but there seems to be a real lack of internal knowledge on how to make it with long drawn out consultations that are conducted in secrecy and then roles out with little noticeable impact; poor internal communication and transparency about change

review_title: Research, Professional Services and Support Teams
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in London, England
pros:
Great atmosphere, amazing Academic and Professional colleagues from all walks of life.  Flexible hours, a joy and great place to work with support and ample opportunities to learn on the jobs and with training, 

The University is going through a modernization in IT, Infrastructure and existing facilities improved to enhance the experience of student.  There is more study spaces, 24 hour library opening hours, hundreds of computing facilities, several shops on Campus, great food in the Canteen providing breakfast, lunch and dinner.

In terms of Student study - Sport facilities, computers, moodle, workshops, additional training and state of the art lecture theaters and rooms, plus hundreds of clubs and societies for leisure.
cons:
As with other Universities  - the education section is now a fully fledged business and operated like one.  Temporary or Contracted staff are employed during transitional operational changes and team restructures - mainly at Management level, and once their objectives or goals are complete - these staff move on back to their agencies to be employed elsewhere.  Thing brings  uncertainty within teams where work carried out by temporary Contractors is unaccountable and any Management/Administration errors  are then handed down the chain when they leave - usually to existing Full Time members of staff to pick up the pieces.

There is also clear a culture of 'long time colleagues and friends'  promoted to senior positions over those that are better suited through qualifications, skills and experience. If you have demonstrated that you follow the 'UCL Vision' - and do as you are asked, regardless of whether it is morally right or wrong you will be looked after and see career progression.  This I believe is the only damning indictment of the UCL Hiring policy where Interview panels are not balanced, not independent where recruitment can be 'fixed'.

review_title: Unique working experience in central London
pros:
- vibrant working environment
- surrounded by bright and determined individuals
- the UCL campus is in central London
- the research staff and colleagues are very helpful and approachable
- I have never experienced any difficulties or differences with other employess
- I quite enjoyed working at UCL
cons:
- you get stuck in student life
- the stipend could be a little bit lacking, especially for an expensive city like London
- they are only a few opportunities to earn a little extra

review_title: Experience as an MRes student at UCL
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in London, England
pros: UCL is a large, highly prestigious university with cutting-edge facilities and resources. It is a great place to learn about and practice experimental physics.
cons: My personal experience of the organisation of the university has been poor. Frequent timetable changes, with lectures or other activities being cancelled, postponed or moved to a new location sometimes hours before their original slot. All changes are communicated via individual emails but there is no centralised timetable online that is frequently updated.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros:
Some world-leading researchers in their fields.
Truly global community.
cons:
Work-life balance in some research group (especially in Engineering Science) can be very bad, and the career progression heavily depends on the internal politics.
The salary for research staff is very low given its Central London location, which makes having family life near impossible unless your partner earns a lot - many promising researchers leave after a few years because of this.

pros: There are many pro's to working here - Great Location. Good reputation. Excellent pension. Cycle to work scheme. Obviously the rest are going to be job/department/manager specific.
cons: More could be done for career progression. There are many courses offered to staff, but these are usually 1 to 2 day one-off courses and very often introductory level. I believe most postdocs are quite capable of acquiring introductory level abilities without these courses. There should be regular advanced options for popular subjects/software due to the nature of the staff.

job_title: Engagement and Communications in London, England
pros: Great location, potential to be a real leader in terms of leading the way for staff and students to be the change that is needed for all our futures.
cons: They say all the right things but actions speak louder than words and business and profit trumps staff/people and the impact they could have on business practices and students

pros:
-Creative
- Supportive
- Well funded
- Growing in size
- Well regarded
- Supportive of entrepreneurial activities
- Provide extensive education of a good quality
- Access to super computing
cons:
- There is a lot of variability between different labs, and so my personal experience may not reflect that of others. 
- As with many institutions of this size, the bureaucracy is slow and plentiful

-

review_title: My career prospects, as a highly-qualified professional, have been damaged by working at UCL
job_title: Professional In Support Department in London, England
pros: (1) Bloomsbury location (2) interesting academic colleagues & students (3) useful in-house IT training
cons: The culture in support departments is typically amateur, authoritarian, bureaucratic, old-fashioned, over-worked, reactive, unjoined-up and poorly-managed. Office accommodation is generally mean

review_title: Amazing supervisors but UCL's admin system is lacking
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in London, England
pros: I had amazing supervision during my PhD, allowing me to become an independent researcher
cons: The administration system at UCL is seriously lacking, meaning late stipend payments and having to pay for yourself to go to a conference and then waiting too long to be refunded, to list a couple of issues!

review_title: Challenging, Inspiring - but you need to be there for the right reason
pros: If you know what you want, and why you're in academia - it's a great place to work. London as a city is unbeatable. But make sure you work with the right people, who can get you places...
cons: The cons are more related to post-doc life in general. Long hours, not enough recognition, hard to move up the ladder.

pros: Easy going, well paid, lots of training on offer, very understanding of needs, managers were generally good people
cons: For me there didn't seem to be any kind of structure or career path, while simultaneously no opportunities to make own decisions, apply for grants, begin own work. Always seemed to be wandering from one project to another, without any capacity to decide own future or knowledge of what the next one might be. Meant few first author publications possible

review_title: A huge and inspiring place to work
pros: Intelligent and motivated colleagues, a rich history and strong research portfolio mean that there are plenty of opportunities for ambitious researchers.  The opportunities for self development are also good, and there is a nice benefits package.
cons: The location mean that it is increasingly difficult to justify the lower wages than the private sector when living in London.  There's a high turnover of staff due to the two-year contracts for research associates.

job_title: Student and Researcher in London, England
pros:
Excellent research standards, esp with sciences.
Very nice people. Supportive staff. And peers.
Excellent teaching, engaging, interesting, diverse.
Truly a top uni when it comes to publications, citations, researchers/academic work.
Great career prospects.
9.5/10
cons:
---Tough workload and pressure
--- Very poor amount of feedback --- when you get a score or report for your work, often very hard to understand what you did wrong and how you can do better next time.
Staff always there to help - but they could save everyone time by providing feedback in the first place.

review_title: Much better reputation than in reality
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: UCL is in the middle of the city. It is a big university with many great research groups. There are great courses available for UCL staff concerning career development etc.
cons: It is hard to get to know other people outside from your research group. The hygiene is bad: it's dirty in the offices, the toilets are most of the time blocked and there are mice everywhere. the hy

pros: it is a very famous school . there's a nice swimming pool . blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah
cons: the H R department is not helping any new comers . i traveled over sea from america to london to work at UCL . however there's no help on relocation . they even gave me the bank letter 2 months after i started the job . the salary was paid late .

review_title: Nice research but admin heavy environment
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in London, England
pros: Potential for collaborations with experts in the field; open culture; initiatives towards diversity; continuing education
cons: I have worked there for 3 years and still have not received/signed a contract that is correct. I had to beg to get the correct salary (although coming from a fellowship) and was paid late fees all in the same tax year, meaning I paid much more taxes on this salary than I should have. Unhelpful HR from my contacts but supportive PI and Head of Department.

pros: Great diversity and social environment. Lots of student clubs and societies to join. Central London. Relatively small campus, thus easy to move around.
cons: Central London, so pretty hard to commute during peak hours. Some lecture rooms are not comfortable and spacious. Libraries are really packed near exam months.

review_title: Experience largely depends on personality and the supervision team
pros: UCL in general provides proper training opportunities and funding for conferences. Supervision team matters for your growth. My supervisors are quite experienced, responsible and pragmatic in research, and I really enjoy studying and working with them.
cons:
International students are charged 4 times the tuition fees as the EU students. 
Teaching opportunities and payments vary among institutes. Some institutes can have very little teaching opportunities.

pros:
Plentiful resources to enable productive research
Openness to individual creativity and critical thinking
Opportunities to provide low-level teaching duties for undergraduates
Industrial collaboration or scale-up readily available through myriad contacts and partners
Flexible work schedule
Lots of funding for travel (conferences, site visits etc)
Ethnic and gender diversity throughout the institution
Lots of parks, pubs and cafes nearby!
cons:
Central London location means living anywhere nearby is difficult and expensive
Disconnect somewhat between departments
Campus and buildings can feel a little cramped (space limitations - though new campus in Stratford under construction)

review_title: Relaxed enviornment but not very exciting
pros: It has a relaxed environment with flexible working hours and sociable co workers. Good location in central London. Easy Commute.
cons: Work is not very challenging. Poor is poor for similar skill set. HR is a joke and cost cutting can make dealing with management a pain.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Impressive range of faculty with eagerness and ability to collaborate. Good frills, for a university (catered meetings, free coffee/tea, good equipment/computers available). Students are knowledgeable. Research money seems to flow more than other universities in the UK.
cons: Support staff tend to be slow on their feet, although average for a UK university. Room is at a premium, and many postdoctoral researchers and even lecturers are asked to share offices.

pros: Intelligent colleagues, central location near good amenities, transparent interview process, many opportunities to collaborate with global institutions
cons: Facilities are very poor.  Very limited space for offices and lecture rooms, poor maintenance of buildings and slow to respond to essential fixing requests, many noise disturbances from equipment, ceremonies, and general city noise, old buildings are too hot in summer and cold in winter.

pros: Great benefits and annual leave (plus several college closure days throughout the year). Commitment to diversity, improving mental health, and making steps towards reducing academic bullying. Very good redundancy payments.
cons: Hierarchical framework of academia still persists and sometimes management aren't forthcoming with promotions (they have to be pushed). Stressful when funding is infrequent. Difficult to find non-lab roles as experience becomes very specialized.

review_title: Reputation based on research, not staff/student experience
pros: Location, reputation, a lot of talented people who are under-utilised.
cons: Shambolic senior management, claim poverty while spending millions on pet projects, poor treatment of staff on lowest grades and contractors, lack of basic facilities, abysmal planning, little effort to build bridges between academics and support staff, increasingly privileged and homogenised intake of students.

pros: World leading university in the heart of London. Very flexible working hours. Able to work from home when not teaching.
cons: Expensive to live in or around London and the London allowance isn't anywhere near enough to make up for this. Some issues with status of teaching fellows: we often get "missed" as we're not considered academics, and are not admin/managerial staff either.

pros:
My particular role offers a lot of autonomy. I am supported but not micromanaged. I got lucky with a good manager. Others not so lucky - some of my colleagues are very unhappy. 

Astrea women's network. 

Interesting events.
cons:
Difficult to progress. Lack of opportunity. 

Overly bureaucratic. IT systems which don't do everything you need them to do. 

Hard to review the entire institution - every department is completely different.

pros: The fellow staff were excellent
cons: Management were very busy restructuring without thinking of impact on staff hours. Led to team moving on as larger results with more evening hours on top of day hours were wanted with less staff.

pros: World Class institute. Good opportunities to get training, funding, help with applications for grants, computer software, transferable skills etc. Well funded
cons: Not many. Can be hard to progress as a basic scientist working in clinical environment. Perhaps, it is easier for clinicians to fast-track to senior positions despite having little scientific expertise.

pros: Working for a big university the pros are as you would expect, good leave, fairly good salary for the sector and job security.
cons: Poor management at many levels. Very little incentive to work harder or make changes.  Pay decided on an incremental basis that stiffles a desire to achieve more.

pros: Access to great equipment with a diverse workforce.
cons:
PIs are not trained as managers. 
There is a culture of bullying, with little in the way of support for those who have experienced bullying or harassment. 
Complaints are handled internally by those who are often directly linked with those who are accused of poor behaviour. This limits confidentiality and often results in retaliation.

pros: Lots of flexibility in work schedule. You are working with some of the best minds in the academic world.  Great people, stimulating environment.  Good training opportunities.  UCL looks good on your resume.
cons: Compensation is typical of academia.  If you are a postdoc, it is definitely best for those determined to pursue an academic career.

review_title: World-class research in a world city
job_title: Principal Research Associate in London, England
pros: Autonomy, respect, career progression, amiable expert colleagues, and a culture built on enlightenment, equality, and independence from government and religion.
cons: London is an expensive place to live: all these opportunities don't come for free. Space is limited, so quite a few researchers work in densely-packed open-plan rooms.

job_title: Programmer Services Coordinator in London, England
pros: Huge highly-regarded organisation with great opportunities. Very dynamic, research across almost every area imaginable, events every day, learning opportunities everywhere you look.  Very good people at every level, great teamwork.
cons: Not nimble and IT needs a great deal of investment. You can get stuck career-wise...

review_title: Great, understanding people in a nurturing environment
pros: Working with cutting edge projectsin a very free environment. Prestigious place to work. Great pension, and very generous leave (41 days). Very talented, down to earth staff. Excellent work-life balance policy!
cons: a little bit eccentric and burocratic at times! Staff resources aren't as good as those provided to students. Salaries a little low.

review_title: My time as research associate at UCL
pros: An overall very good institution which is striving to be at the very forefront of research and development. At the same time it is a very pleasant place to work.
cons: Since the main part of the campus is located in the centre of the city, there is often a problem with space and it is not uncommon that you have 5-6 persons in an office.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: A top tier university full of great thinkers and amazing researchers/academics to work with. The institute also provides staff with various courses/training, both academic and career-wise.
cons: The main campus is apparently constantly short of space for both students and staff. Working environment could be quite intense and hostile every now and then due to overcrowding (space shortage) and stresses and strains of research/administrative workloads.

review_title: Great for an easy work life
pros: Relaxed environment, time is flexible and casual atmosphere
cons: Scarce promotional opportunities for lower grade staff even of good ability and often given dead end jobs with no chance of advancement; automatic promotional opportunies for senior staff even of mediocre ability.

review_title: Avoid the Library Services department - horrendous
pros:
Unfortunately, there are few ...

- Access to a fantastic library collection completely free of charge
- Interacting with a large and diverse student population
- For the proactive, opportunities to volunteer with the 'Special Collections" team who have access to some amazing artefacts which few people get to see
- Central location - the British Museum is just around the corner!
cons:
In short, if you can avoid this institution, do; or at least avoid employment within the front-line, customer service teams. The management team is responsible for creating and perpetuating a strong culture of bullying, harassment, and blame passing. This is common, widespread knowledge amongst staff, yet despite this, and innumerable complaints from multiple staff members to those in a position of power and authority (directors), no action is taken to eradicate this unprofessional and harmful behaviour.

Consequently, there has been an exodus of excellent, intelligent and qualified people who have sought employment at other HE institutions, leaving behind poor employees who have no place in customer services. 

Furthermore, the departmental HR team is in complete disarray and you're lucky if you get paid correctly from month to month. I know of several colleagues who have claimed and received large amounts of compensation due to the ineptitude of this team.

Further cons include:
- an absence of support and motivation from your superior
- no career progression opportunities
- an absence of basic training to fulfil your role
- ironically, it's a non-challenging and non-stimulating environment
- an inability to contribute ideas and suggestions  - no opportunities are extended and feedback offered freely is dismissed
- poor standard of/inadequate staff facilities 
- dirty environment which attracts pests (the cleaners are fantastic and do the best they can. Unfortunately, their team is perpetually understaffed so they do not have the resources to clean adequately)

review_title: A good research environment but competitive culture
pros: Many opportunities for collaboration are available to UCL researchers. Generally there is a high standard and range of equipment and facilities available which help progress research faster.
cons: Burn out work ethic is pushed by most PIs. There is a competitive culture in some teams due to funding being so tough to get.

pros: The culture is very laid back and there is a lot of flexibility in terms of working hours and work/lifestyle balance
cons: There is little opportunity for career advancement and senior management was less than helpful in terms of career advice and guidance

job_title: Postgraduate Teaching Assistant (F6) in London, England
pros: It is quite an international university. Here we can make friends across the world and they are all friendly. The facilities are nice, and the teachers are great. There are also many career-related events for the students to better prepare for their future.
cons: At the centre of London, the campus is relatively small. Actually there is no campus at all - buildings span in different areas.

pros:
- Very flexible
- Nice to speak to young students, encourage them to consider university as an option
- Good pay for a student job
- Easy to do and lots of fun perks
cons:
- Can be a little boring with not much to do
- They try to give everyone a chance to work so you can be limited in how much you can earn per term.

pros: It provides a variety of tools and opportunities that greatly improve the quality of learning. What  differentiates it from other top Universities is its eclectic atmosphere given my world leading departments in a variety of subjects. This really make life more enjoyable and gives the opportunity to know different people and to feel other departments as well.
cons: cost of housing and lack of discounts for UCL students

pros: This is a place that you can grow in intellect and personally in all ways which is a benefit to everyone
cons: The hours can be long but this is usually self inflicted and can change if you want it to over time

pros:
Decent salary

Generous annual leave and pension benefits for staff
cons:
The HR Services Team from the Professional Services Hub are useless - managed by incompetent managers

The Transforming Our Professional Services project will mean that Payroll staff will be redundant and likely forced to take jobs in HR Services on a lower grade.

pros: High ranking university, HQ of a lot of famous researchers, access to funded projects, generally good research environment
cons: Not enough support for PhD and graduate students, not enough support to find means of funding, the bureaucracy is hellish and departments have no links between them or with the general body, everything takes ages to be completed

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in London, England
pros: Large and prestigious University. Large union very well established and many tools to facilitate work/life balance (in theory)
cons: Like all academic setup, it largely depends on your line manager. It's difficult to bypass that level if there are issues because research groups are tightly under the PI control. The pension scheme is under attack meaning effective salaries and benefits are not so attractive anymore

job_title: Postgraduate Teaching Assistant in London, England
pros: Flexible hours, candidates submit their hour preferences when they apply. A lot of opportunities to take courses in teaching. Non-UCL PhDs can apply.
cons: For some PhDs it may be hard to find a module, that would more or less closely relate to their own research. Not much space for your own ideas: a PGTA is basically a facilitator to the module coordinator.

review_title: A very friendly environment with people from all over the world.
pros: Located in the centre of the city, with many opportunities to work on. A variety of departments is provided with people with lots of skills in each domain.
cons: Working in such an environment although it is a great experience is very stressful. There is a lot of competition and all the programmes are  intensive

pros: Best professors and best environment. Look forward to seeking the combination of digital technologies and built environments.
cons: Not too much connections between the tutor and students expect class time. Complex place for lecture makes people confused.

review_title: Pretty nice work environment -facilities could be better
pros:
Uni has a good reputation
Challenging work
Nice to get a desk in a small office
cons:
Expensive

Facilities are poor e.g: air con doesn't always work in summer, in winter estates turn the heating up very high, it's hard to find a room to book, everything is very busy when the undergrads are in, there's no nice green space to walk in.

review_title: UCL is a good place to do academic research.
pros:
- technical facilities are great
- career development options are excellent
- flexible working hours
cons: - not a very productive or motivating research environment, but this depends on the laboratory

review_title: Great atmosphere in the heart of London
pros: Location location location! Reputation, academic atmosphere, opportunities for collaborations; opportunities for cross-disciplinary research. Good local restaurants, good travel links. Modern campus with traditional feel.
cons: London weighting doesn't put you on a par with the rest of the country, so you are worse off overall.

review_title: Great place to work over all
job_title: Clinical Data Manager in London, England
pros: Get to work with some great diverse groups of people. Good access to training courses and other things to aid your personal and professional development. Great flexibility and good work life balance.
cons: Can be difficult to progress/ get promotions. They'd rather hire people fro outside of UCL than those who are already working there.

pros: Great research going on, lots of talented scientists and students, good seminar series enabling one to keep track of work in other fields.
cons: Labs feel isolated from each other, often long hours and working at weekends. Things take a very long time to get done

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Stimulating work environment , and colleagues at work were friendly. In charge of your day, at least in the lab I worked - not always the case
cons: Inequality still present at the higher positions, less women making it to top positions in comparison to men, with a lot more women at lower levels

pros:
Good location. 

Students represent a diverse group. 

Appear to actively champion female students and staff, and has visible policies against discrimination of almost all kinds.

Some very good and helpful departmental staff, and academics and students seem pleasant overall.
cons:
Severe lack of space

Some departmental support staff appear unhelpful and grumpy which makes for an unpleasant working environment. Requests for support are met with disdain and bad attitude.

review_title: Good, but needs to get better
pros: Central location is ideal and convenient, with easy access to food, shops and transport. The equality, diversity and inclusion initiative is trying in earnest to improve conditions within the department and university.
cons: Cramped spaces often due to the lack of space available. Admin team can take a long time to process simple requests.

review_title: Working at UCL - pros and cons
pros: World leading experts in research, fun and passionate people, lots of interesting seminars to attend
cons: Some PhD students are left on their own without a lot of support during the years. Best approach would be to take initiative and start looking for people who can collaborate with you and can help.

review_title: PhD in a systems neuroscience lab in UCL
pros: Very broad neuroscience community, vast resources, big labs crowded with talented postdocs to guide research as well as small labs with a closer mentorship from the PI depending on the mentorship style you desire.
cons: Need to actively engage with the community to be seen, very few casual gatherings across labs.

review_title: awesome culture, one of the finest places to study
pros: its a multicultural university where the environment is most apt for development. hence a lifetime experience for any individual to study at such a place.
cons: the university is spread all over the city and thus its hard to travel to different classrooms at different times.

pros: Flexible working hours, good public sector salary scheme, pension scheme, central location, lively university campus, good lunch facilities, good social facilities for staff.
cons: Some IT hardware and software problematical and in need of updating, communication with some members of management staff was too limited, staff were sent on too many training programmes that were unnecessary.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Respected big university. Will look great on your CV, dependent on your research achievements. World leading scientists and friendly relaxed environment.
cons: Overcrowded facilities. HR, pension team and other admin stuff are not responsive and also not very supportive, instead of helping you out with issues they create issues.

pros: Smart people, good location, world class opportunities, prestige,
cons: low pay, in London...

review_title: Very good scientific and learning place
pros: Very good logistical conditions, training opportunities for young researchers, many career workshops. I am also involved in a very interesting project with all the measurement instruments needed.
cons: The administration staff is quite out-numbered at times and their payment processing is very old and it's even done manually.

pros: Availability of multiple projects and plenty of great supervisors, network of other students is also an advantage. UCL is generally a great place to do a PhD due to its active research community.
cons: I don't particularly like London but that's just a personal preference.

pros: They have recently allowed tenure track promotions all the way to Professor without need for research.
cons: Although rated very high academically, they do not integrate departments well, so it is still very silo based.

pros: Only Imperial pays better in London
cons: Cramped campus, management care more about cramming in as many students as possible than creating enough space to function effectively.

review_title: PhD student at University College London
pros:
A great pool of expertise from different background who are willing to share their knowledge and experiences.
A wide range of exciting projects. 
Have researchers from different countries and cultures.
Vibrant working environment.
Enjoy interacting with undergraduate students
cons: Office space is limited - there are not enough desks for phd students

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Access to expertise in broad range of subjects. Access to UCL library and online journals. Great potential for networking/collaboration.
cons: For a postdoctoral research associate there is no defined career structure other than that of academic group leader career track.

pros: Very International in composition. Strong careers division that helps at every step. Great exposure to opportunities. Very centrally located in London. Great brand name. Very innovative in some initiatives.
cons: Salary compensation not great. Crosstalk between departments/ institutes within UCL limited. Bit conserved in approach. High university fees and almost no campus accommodation. Administration bottleneck.

review_title: Great place for early career researchers
pros: The opportunity to work for/with world class leaders in research. My programme enabled us to attend interesting seminars and workshops as well as student symposia and retreats.
cons: Some departments/labs are in poor conditions due to the lack of funding.. this affects the admin and research side unfortunately

pros: UCL is a great university with an exciting network and student community. it links you to the best companies and supports through all the stages of your career building.
cons: During my 4 years at UCL, I have noticed that sometimes the administrative departments require long time to deal with general paperwork.

pros:
Welcoming intellectual environment.
Funds to attend conferences and international workshops. 
Discounted gym facilities. Bloomsbury is lovely.
cons:
I had some trouble getting technical advice for my project, and on many occasions I felt like I was working by myself. 

I should say that your experience will vary wildly depending on your department and research group.

job_title: WT PhD Student in London, England
pros:
Good stipend for a PhD
Interesting projects to work with
cons:
Sink or swim attitude from management
Stressful work environment
PhD students seen by PIs as a cheap (free) labour

pros: Supervisors available to you are the top of their respective fields. Support services such as careers advice and mental health support/physical health support are readily available.
cons: Dependent on your supervisor, you may have fewer contact hours with them than you would like. Make sure to choose a supervisor well.

pros: Top university, excellent facilities. Great work life balance. Always good seminars and guest speakers - plenty of opportunity for career development.
cons: Perhaps not as much collaboration between different groups within the computer science department as I would have liked. Plenty of opportunity for crossover between different fields.

job_title: Senior Teaching Fellow in London, England
pros: a good employer with good career progression and attention to staff and support for their work and a good salary and perks
cons: good supportive structures for academic careers in place and  communication with top management is second to none. would be very difficult to find anything to say against them.

pros: Work-life balance, benefits, opportunities for training and quite laid back. You are given time to get things done. Good location
cons: It can get quite boring after a while. The organisation moves at a very slow pace and it takes ages to get things done.

pros:
-good research which is focused on a specific area
-learn new techniques in the wet lab
-perform own research
-flexible working hours
cons:
-academic politics
-supervisor can be a control freak but this depends on your supervisor
-you can lose your research project and ideas to your colleagues
-toilets are awful
-no air con in the summer months

review_title: It probably depends on your position/section in the big university..
pros:
Where I am, in a relatively small sub-programme that is quite independent, my immediate colleagues are pleasant, and the working environment is ok.
Good computer equipment provided.
Access to journal subscriptions is valuable for me.
cons:
Conversely to above, there has been some nasty power games including personal attacks that haven't been addressed by management.
My role function is badly under-resourced that causes professional difficulties.
Management tends to top-heavy and disorganised, and I have had a bordeline-abusive manager.

pros: I think UCL departments are very positive to learn as a researcher, the environment is adequate to learning and progression. I think the best element is the opportunity to learn in conjunction with other students or university staff
cons: Perhaps a lack of coordination between some administrative organisations/teams

pros: Extremely supportive environment. Very engaging and flexible in terms of research schedule. A very good learning experience to gain insight in actual lab environment.
cons: Difficult to find ways to continue/move up the career ladder, such as finding overseas funding for PhD, despite the extensive support from supervisor.

review_title: Good work place, hard to get full time position
job_title: Senior Research Associate in London, England
pros: Good opportunities for professional development, collaboration with colleagues, time flexibility, big and active scientific community, liberal vision, openness.
cons: Not great attention to the individual employee. Too much attention on students' needs. Not many opportunities of career advancement due to large competition for positions.

pros: Good communication between management, plenty of opportunities for development, great central location, generous salary, the workload is usually very manageable.
cons: There aren't that many cons, although, the IT system is generally quite poor and every day there seems to another problem. Onsite Cafes can be horrendously expensive for lunch

review_title: A great place to work in the heart of London
pros:
Lots of students from all over the world.
World class research.
cons:
Some of the labs are a bit dated.
Often felt like not enough teaching space for the number of students.

pros: World-class academic environment with one of the most renowned engineering research in the UK and in the world.

The engineering dept. building is crammed with people. 
Not enough working spaces for an ever growing number or students and research staff.

review_title: Queen Square Brain Bank post doc
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in London, England
pros: Great colleagues, fun and relatively laid back environment which inspires open collaboration and team work.

pros:
Location, great team, everyone is professional and helpful.
Benefits, including generous holiday and generous pension. Also great ambassadors for part-time working and flexi-working
cons: Very large organisation (16,000 staff) so can be bureaucratic to get things done.

pros:
New and shiny and should get even better when the new building goes live.

cons: Removed from the main campus and as such lacks convenient access to some resources. Not a lot going on in the social aspect.

pros: State of the art facilities, competitive, many opportunities, no finance problem, collaborations, freedom

pros: Good pay, holiday and other conditions and convenient location.

review_title: Amazing colleagues and research environment, everything else mostly bad
pros:
- amazing colleagues that you can easily learn from or start collaborations

- great location in central London
